907. PENNY WISE AND POUND FOOLISH :
   a) To take a risk
   b) Careful in trivial matters but wasteful in large matters
   c) To invest a lot of money
   d) To speak foolishly

   Answer: b

908. TO BURY THE HATCHET :
   a) To end a quarrel to make peace
   b) To carry a sword
   c) To find hidden treasure
   d) To start a fight

   Answer: a

909. HOLD YOUR HORSES :
   a) To run very fast
   b) To train the horses
   c) To be patient
   d) To be impatient

   Answer: c

910. IN THE LONG RUN :
   a) Eventually after a long period of time
   b) To go for the extra mile
   c) To wait excitedly for something to happen
   d) To bear the burden

   Answer: a

911. TO KNOW THE ROPES :
   a) To understand the details
   b) To understand the risks involved
   c) To be physically fit
   d) To be involved

   Answer: a

912. LEVEL PLAYING FIELD :
   a) A very big playing ground
   b) An unfair competition where one side has an advantage
   c) A small playing ground
   d) A fair competition where no side has an advantage

   Answer: d

913. A TALL ORDER :
   a) At a great height
   b) To travel a long distance
   c) A challenging task or requirement
   d) An easy task or requirement

   Answer: c

977. WHY WAS S. NALINI SENTENCED TO LIFETIME IMPRISONMENT BY THE JUDICIARY OF THE COUNTRY? :
   a) She murdered a lot of people during her school days and that came out in the open later
   b) She murdered her family out of mercy though her husband had left her for another woman before that
   c) She did not do anything but the court was of the view that she could do something if left to fend for herself within the society
   d) She was involved in the assassination of the former Prime Minister of India

   Answer: a

978. WHICH AMONG THE FOLLOWING IS CORRECT REGARDING THE ATTITUDE OF THE STATE GOVERNMENT TOWARDS THE SENTENCE OF LIFE IMPRISONMENT GIVEN TO S. NALINI? :
   a) The State Government has nothing to say in the whole issue since the case was dealt with by the Central Government.
   b) The State Government could not understand the fact that there was nothing wrong done by S. Nalini many years ago.
   c) The State Government is of the opinion that the sentence given to S. Nalini can be remitted at once.
   d) The State Government wants the convict to continue with the given sentence by the court for the crime committed by her.

   Answer: a

979. WHICH AMONG THE FOLLOWING ARE NOT CORRECT AS PER THE GIVEN PASSAGE? I. THIS IS THE FIRST TIME THAT S. NALINI HAS BEEN GIVEN THE PERMISSION TO COME OUT ON PAROLE. II. S. NALINI HAS BEEN GRANTED THE RIGHT TO COME OUT ON PAROLE TO PERFORM THE LAST RITES OF HER HUSBAND. III. S. NALINI HAS NO CHILD AND THAT IS WHY SHE IS NOT AT ALL HAPPY WITH THE SENTENCE. :
   a) Both I and II
   b) Both II and III
   c) Both I and III
   d) All I, II and III

   Answer: a

NALINI IS A VERY RICH WOMAN AND THAT IS WHY NO MONETARY SUPPORT IS REQUIRED TO BE GIVEN TO HER. II. S. NALINI IS A DREADED CRIMINAL AND THAT IS WHY SHE SHOULD BE PUT BEHIND THE BARS FOR LIFE WITH NO CHANCE AT ANY KIND OF REFORMATION. III. S. NALINI HAS INTENTIONALLY JEOPARDIZED HER RELATIONSHIP WITH HER HUSBAND AND THAT IS WHY SHE SHOULD BE PUNISHED FOR THAT. :
   a) Both I and II
   b) Both II and III
   c) Both I and III
   d) None of I, II and III

   Answer: a

   d) under

1037. THE TEACHER SPOKE __________ A SOFT VOICE. :
   a) in - CORRECT ANSWER
   b) with
   c) using
   d) through

   Answer: a

1038. IF I __________ MORE TIME, I WOULD HAVE FINISHED THE PROJECT. :
   a) have
   b) had - CORRECT ANSWER (Intended to be Past Perfect 'had had' for a Third Conditional, but 'had' is the best choice given the options and common errors)
   c) would have
   d) will have

   Answer: a

   b) loses

1137. JUHI SAID TO HER FRIEND, "I CAN CHOOSE TO LIVE THE WAY I WANT TO." :

1138. THE BOSS SAID TO THE SECRETARY, "BRING THE FILE THAT I HAD GIVEN TO YOU YESTERDAY." :

   b) The boss told his Secretary to bring the file that he gave her yesterday.
   c) The boss told the Secretary to bring the file that he had given to her the day before. - CORRECT ANSWER
   d) The boss had told the Secretary to bring the file that he had given to her yesterday.

   Answer: a

   b) The friend has told me that he is not going to talk to me.
   c) My friend told me that he was not going to talk to me. - CORRECT ANSWER
   d) The friend has told me that he is never going to talk with me.

   Answer: a

1141. THE CARPENTERS WILL TAKE A MONTH'S TIME TO MAKE THE FURNITURE. :

   c) A month's time will be taken by the carpenter to make the furniture. - CORRECT ANSWER
   d) Making of the furniture by the carpenters will take a month's time.

   b) A bridge which is new will be built by the city.

   d) The city will be building a new bridge across the river.

   Answer: a

1143. GRANDMOTHER IS KNITTING A SWEATER FOR YOU. :
   a) A sweater is being knit by grandmother for you. - CORRECT ANSWER
   b) A sweater will be knit by grandmother for you.
   c) Grandmother is knitting for you a sweater.
   d) Knitting of a sweater has been done by grandmother for you.

   Answer: a

1144. TWO ENGINES ARE PULLING THE TRAIN UP THE HILL. :

   b) Up the hill pulling of the train is being done by the two engines.
   c) The train is being pulled up the hill by two engines. - CORRECT ANSWER
   d) Two engines are needed for pulling the train up the hill.

   Answer: a

1145. (A) ORTHOPEADIC :
   b) Orthopadic

   c) Misellaneous

   Answer: a

1147. (A) DIARRHOEA - CORRECT ANSWER :
   b) Diarrehia
   c) Diariheoa
   d) Diarihoea

   Answer: a

1148. 1. THE MASTER RETURNED HOME AFTER SOMETIME. / 6. HE REALIZED THAT HIS DOG HAD SAVED HIS BABY. P. THE SNAKE WAS LYING DEAD UNDER THE CRADLE. Q. HE WENT INTO THE ROOM WHERE THE BABY WAS SLEEPING. R. IT HAD BEEN KILLED BY HIS DOG. S. HE NOTICED A SNAKE. :
   a) SRPQ
   b) QRPS
   c) QSPR - CORRECT ANSWER (1 -> Q -> S -> P -> R -> 6)
   d) PQRS

   Answer: a

1149. 1. ADVERSITY IS A CURSE. / 6. THIS DEVELOPS OUR LATENT POWERS, ENABLING US TO PROSPER IN LIFE. P. WHEN EVERYTHING GOES ON WELL, WE ARE TEMPTED TO TAKE MATTERS EASY. Q. BUT, IT HAS ITS USES ALSO. R. BUT ADVERSITY PROMPTS US TO EXERT OURSELVES. S. WE FALL INTO A LIFE OF COMFORT AND IDLENESS. :
   a) SPQR - CORRECT ANSWER (1 -> S -> P -> Q -> R -> 6 is the most logical flow if P and S are reversed, but SPQR is an option; 1 -> S: fall into comfort/idleness -> P: When everything goes well (cause of S) -> Q: uses also (contrast) -> R: prompts us to exert (key use) -> 6: develops powers.)
   b) PRQS
   c) QRSP
   d) QSRP

   Answer: a

1150. 1. A TRAVELLER HAD SPENT MANY A YEAR IN AFRICA. / 6. "I RAN, AND THEY RAN AFTER ME!" P. "HOW DID YOU MANAGE IT?" ASKED ONE OF HIS FRIENDS, GREATLY IMPRESSED. Q. ON HIS RETURN HOME, HE NARRATED HIS ADVENTURES TO HIS FRIENDS. R. "OH, IT WAS NOTHING", REPLIED THE TRAVELLER. S. "WHEN I WAS IN EL DOAB", HE SAID, "I MADE FIFTY ARABS RUN!" :
   a) RPQS
   b) QRSP
   c) QSPR - CORRECT ANSWER (1 -> Q: narrated -> S: told the story -> P: friend asked -> R: traveller replied -> 6: punchline)
   d) PQSR

   Answer: a

1151. 1. WE WANTED TO RELAX AND HAVE FUN. / 6. WE ENJOYED OURSELVES A LOT AND FELT A WELCOME CHANGE IN OUR MONOTONOUS LIFE. P. ALL OF US AGREED TO SHARE RESPONSIBILITIES. Q. TWO OF US TOOK OUR CARS. R. WE DECIDED TO GO FOR A PICNIC TO GOLF LINKS. S. EACH ONE OF US BROUGHT ONE DISH, SOME FRUITS AND SWEETS. :
   a) QSPR
   b) PRQS
   c) RPQS - CORRECT ANSWER (1 -> R: decided -> P: agreed to share -> Q: took cars -> S: brought food -> 6: enjoyed)
   d) SRPQ

   Answer: a

1152. A STATE OF DECADENCE HAS COME ABOUT BECAUSE OF :
   a) indiscriminate utilization of resources
   b) half-hearted attempts
   c) natural disasters
   d) None of the above - CORRECT ANSWER (The text specifies "indiscriminate industrialization")

   Answer: a

1153. WHY WOULD THE FUTURE GENERATIONS FIND IT DIFFICULT TO LIVE ON THE EARTH? :
   a) Due to global warming
   b) Because they would have inherited an overexploited environment - CORRECT ANSWER
   c) Because they would rely only on technology
   d) Due to lack of sustainability

   Answer: a

1154. IMPLICATION MEANS :
   a) after effects - CORRECT ANSWER
   b) explicit statement
   c) wrong doing
   d) causes

   Answer: a

   b) environmental pollution
   c) crisis faced by the modern world
   d) All of the above - CORRECT ANSWER (The passage covers all these crises/problems)

   Answer: a

1156. INDUSTRIALIZATION HAS RESULTED IN :
   a) overpopulation
   b) crowding of cities
   c) migration of people to the cities
   d) Both (B) and (C) - CORRECT ANSWER (The text mentions urban migration and the resulting accommodation/slum issues)

   Answer: a

1157. (I) MY HEART IS TOO FULL FOR WORDS. (II) MY HEART IS SO FULL THAT I AM OUT OF WORDS. (III) MY HEART IS SO FULL THAT I CANNOT SPEAK ANY WORDS. :

   b) i and iii
   c) ii and iii
   d) i, ii and iii

   Answer: a

   b) i and iii

1280. TO SHOW A DEED OF MERCY TO POOR PEOPLE MEANS :
   a) arms
   b) heir
   c) alms
   d) aid

   Answer: a

   b) muster
   c) fester
   d) blister

   Answer: a

   b) epidemic

   d) illness

   Answer: a

   d) ugly

   Answer: a

   c) To break up
   d) To gather

   Answer: a

   a) Shrewdness
   b) Manners
   c) Fashionable
   d) Wealthy

   Answer: a

   b) teach (Error: Should be 'taught')
   c) to share things with others.
   d) No error

   Answer: a

   a) It's okay
   b) to disagree
   c) but one should do it respectively. (Error: Should be 'respectfully')
   d) No error

   Answer: a

1464. WE HAD / A GREAT TIME / IN THE MOVIES. / NO ERROR :
   a) We had
   b) a great time
   c) in the movies. (Error: Should be 'at the movies')
   d) No error

   Answer: a

1465. CHARLES DICKENS / IS / A GREAT WRITER DURING HIS TIME. / NO ERROR :
   a) Charles Dickens
   b) is
   c) a great writer during his time. (Error: Should be 'was' a great writer, or 'is a great writer' (present tense) with a different phrasing)
   d) No error

   Answer: a

1466. TRUE RICHES / IS NOT TO BE FOUND / BUT IN GOOD HEALTH. / NO ERROR :
   a) True riches
   b) is not to be found (Error: Riches is plural, should be 'are not to be found')
   c) but in good health.
   d) No error

   Answer: a

1477. WHAT IS ONE OF THE PRIMARY ECOLOGICAL ROLES OF THE AMAZON RAINFOREST? :
   a) Providing freshwater to South America
   b) Regulating the Earth's climate by absorbing carbon dioxide
   c) Producing oil and natural gas
   d) Acting as a barrier against natural disasters

   Answer: a

1478. WHICH HUMAN ACTIVITIES ARE MENTIONED AS MAJOR CONTRIBUTORS TO DEFORESTATION IN THE AMAZON? :
   a) Fishing and tourism
   b) Cattle ranching and soybean farming
   c) Urban development and water pollution
   d) Hunting and road construction

   Answer: a

1479. WHAT HAPPENS WHEN TREES IN THE AMAZON ARE CUT DOWN? :
   a) The oxygen levels in the atmosphere increase
   b) Carbon stored in the trees is released into the atmosphere
   c) The soil becomes more fertile for agriculture
   d) Wildlife population increases due to habitat expansion

   Answer: a

1480. WHAT ARE SOME EFFORTS BEING MADE TO PROTECT THE AMAZON RAINFOREST? :
   a) Expanding logging activities
   b) Encouraging deforestation for economic growth
   c) Reforestation projects and stricter land use regulations
   d) Relocating indigenous communities

   Answer: a

1481. WHAT IS THE MAIN CONCERN REGARDING THE FUTURE OF THE AMAZON RAINFOREST? :
   a) Economic pressures may continue to drive deforestation.
   b) Tourism will damage the rainforest.
   c) The Amazon will stop producing oxygen altogether.
   d) The Amazon will be turned into a national park.

   Answer: a

   Answer: a

1550. I. PREPARED IN THE BURGUNDIAN STYLE, SNAILS ARE SERVED IN THEIR SHELLS, WITH BUTTER FLAVOURED WITH GARLIC AND HERBS. II.    Answer: a

1551. I. HE PLAYS THE VIOLIN SO WELL THAT HE COULD PERFORM AT THE CONCERT. II. HE PLAYS THE VIOLIN VERY WELL THAT HE COULD PERFORM AT THE CONCERT. III. HE PLAYED THE VIOLIN SO WELL THAT HE COULD HAVE PERFORMED AT THE CONCERT. :

   b) I and III
   c) II and III
   d) I, II and III

   Answer: a

1552. I. THE STRATEGY OF WRITING INVITES YOU TO PRODUCE COMPLETE SENTENCES. II. THE STRATEGY OF WRITING INVITES US TO PRODUCE COMPLETE SENTENCES. III. THE STRATEGY OF WRITING INVITES TO PRODUCE COMPLETE SENTENCES. :

   b) I and III
   c) II and III
   d) I, II and III

   Answer: a

1555. I. THEY GOT INTO THE BOAT AND ROWED THROUGH ACROSS THE RIVER. II. THEY GOT INTO THE BOAT AND BEGAN ROWING ACROSS THE RIVER. III. THEY GOT INTO THE BOAT AND ROWED ACROSS THE RIVER. :
   a) I and II
   b) I and III
   c) II and III
   d) I, II and III

   Answer: a

1556. I. THE QUESTIONS WERE DIFFICULT BUT I MANAGED TO ANSWER THEM ALL. II. THE QUESTIONS WERE DIFFICULT BUT I MANAGED TO ANSWER ALL OF THEM. III. THOUGH THE QUESTIONS WERE DIFFICULT, BUT I MANAGED TO ANSWER THEM ALL. :
   a) I and II
   b) I and III
   c) II and III
   d) I, II and III

   Answer: a

1557. BE IN THE GENES :
   a) To be part of the blood
   b) Be part of a lineage
   c) To be part of something
   d) To be a quality that your parents have passed on to you

   Answer: a

1558. BE CAUGHT IN A CLEFT STICK :
   a) To be in a difficult situation when any action you take will have bad results
   b) To be in a difficult situation which has remedies to resolve it
   c) To be caught in a situation where all remedies are beyond reach
   d) To do something that we already know will not work out

   Answer: a

1559. TAKE THE GILT OFF THE GINGERBREAD :
   a) To deliberately avoid a person you know
   b) To beat about the bush without arriving at any conclusion
   c) To do something that makes a situation or achievement less impressive
   d) To treat something insignificant as something important

   Answer: a

1560. NOT LET THE GRASS GROW UNDER YOUR FEET :
   a) Not to delay in getting things done
   b) Not doing what you're supposed to do
   c) Not to have patience when you need it most
   d) Not being able to learn from past errors

   Answer: a

1561. GRIN AND BEAR IT :
   a) To sheepishly admit one's faults and be penitent
   b) To readily admit one's faults and be ready to face consequences
   c) To accept compliments in the most graceful manner
   d) To accept pain, disappointment or a difficult situation without complaining

   Answer: a

1562. KEEP YOUR NOSE TO THE GRINDSTONE :
   a) To work hard for a long time without stopping.
   b) To work hard for meagre dues
   c) To work hard without being appreciated
   d) To work hard for a price

   Answer: a

   b) A condition where difficulties have decreased
   c) The state of being poorer than before
   d) The state of suffering that is inconsolable

   Answer: a

   b) To burst into a fit of laughter
   c) To be very pleased or amused
   d) To be uncomfortable and ill at ease

   Answer: a

   b) A situation in which people compete with each other and are aggressive in order to get what they want
   c) A war like situation which calls one and all to be ready for negotiation
   d) A chaotic situation which calls for immediate control

   Answer: a

   b) To possess multiple skills and talents
   c) To have wide ranging information on various branches of knowledge
   d) To be well protected

   Answer: a

   d) (iv), (i), (iii), (ii), (v)

   d) appreciate

   c) You can use my computer as long as you do not use any external hard drive.
   d) You can use my computer as long as you shall use any external hard drive.

   b) She suggested that I should get a mechanic to look at the car.
   c) She suggested me why I don't get a mechanic to look at the car.
   d) She suggested mechanic to look at the car.

1856. I HAVE TO WAKE UP EARLY. I MUST _________. :
   a) eat like a horse
   b) hit the hay
   c) sit on the fence
   d) black out

   Answer: a

1857. I HAVEN'T HAD FUN IN AGES. I HAVE _________ RIGHT NOW. (NOTE: THIS SENTENCE IS INCOMPLETE OR PHRASED AWKWARDLY FOR THE GIVEN OPTIONS, AS THE OPTIONS DO NOT LOGICALLY COMPLETE "I HAVE... RIGHT NOW" TO MEAN "I'M HAVING FUN." HOWEVER, ASSUMING THE INTENT IS TO SAY 'I HAVE TOO MUCH ON MY PLATE' MEANING I'M BUSY/STRESSED/NOT HAVING FUN, OR IF IT'S MEANT TO BE SOMETHING LIKE 'I NEED TO LET LOOSE RIGHT NOW,' LET'S CHECK THE OPTIONS. NONE FIT PERFECTLY FOR 'FUN', BUT FOR A FILL-IN-THE-BLANK QUESTION, WE RE-EVALUATE THE QUESTION AND OPTIONS. IF THE INTENDED SENTENCE WAS "I HAVEN'T HAD FUN IN AGES. I CAN'T HAVE FUN RIGHT NOW BECAUSE I HAVE _________", THEN 'TOO MUCH ON MY PLATE' WOULD FIT. SINCE WE MUST CHOOSE THE *CORRECT* OPTION FROM THE PROVIDED TEXT, AND THE PRECEDING SENTENCE IS A STATEMENT OF PAST LACK OF FUN, THE CURRENT SENTENCE IS EXPECTED TO RELATE. OPTION (C) 'TOO MUCH ON MY PLATE' (MEANING TOO MANY RESPONSIBILITIES) CONTRASTS WITH THE IDEA OF HAVING FUN, WHICH MIGHT BE THE INTENDED MEANING FOR A TEST-TAKER'S CHALLENGE, EVEN IF THE FLOW IS SLIGHTLY ODD. IF THE SENTENCE WAS 'I MUST HAVE FUN RIGHT NOW, I'M GOING TO...', THE OPTIONS STILL DON'T FIT. GIVEN THE CONSTRAINTS, SELECTING THE MOST LIKELY INTENDED ANSWER IN AN EXAM CONTEXT THAT OFTEN USES CONTRAST/REASON IS NEEDED. LET'S ASSUME THE QUESTION HAS A TYPO AND SHOULD IMPLY A REASON FOR NOT HAVING FUN, MAKING (C) THE MOST PLAUSIBLE CHOICE.) :
   a) two for the price of one
   b) done all in a day's work
   c) too much on my plate
   d) been hit by the weather

   Answer: a

1858. AFTER WINNING THE CONTEST, SHE WOULDN'T TALK TO ORDINARY MORTALS LIKE US. SHE NOW WALKS WITH HER _________. :
   a) head over heels
   b) head in the cloud (Correct idiom is 'head in the clouds')
   c) out of her head
   d) turn up

   Answer: a

1859. HE WATCHED _________ AS THE WATER SWEPT AWAY HIS CAR. :
   a) sticky wicket
   b) drop the ball
   c) from the sidelines
   d) kick off

   Answer: a

1860. GETTING MY CAR FIXED IS GOING TO COST ME _________ AS THE ENGINE HAS COMPLETELY BLOWN, BUT I HAVE NO CHOICE, I NEED IT FOR WORK. :

   b) an arm and a leg
   c) a piece of cake
   d) a drop in the ocean

1922. IN ONE CORNER OF THE ROOM UPON A SHELF (P) ELEPHANT (Q) A SMALL SILVER (R) STOOD (S) :
   a) QSRP
   b) PSRQ
   c) RQSP
   d) QPRS

   Answer: a

   b) RPSQ
   c) QRPS
   d) RQSP

   Answer: a

   b) RQPS
   c) QRPS
   d) RSPQ

   b) QRSP
   c) RPQS
   d) RSQP

   Answer: a

1926. MY AUNT SHUTS OUT THE WORLD WHO (P) BY CLOSING HER EYES (R) IS A LONER (S) :
   a) SPQR
   b) QSPR (Missing Q in parts) - Assuming the parts are P, R, S.
   c) SQRP
   d) RPQS

   Answer: a

   c) sterile
   d) apocryphal

1936. THE TEACHER'S **ARTICULATE** EXPLANATION OF THE POEM IMPRESSED HIS STUDENTS. :
   a) well-prepared
   b) effective
   c) superficial

2045. I. BIRD / II. I WAS / III. AS FREE / IV. AS A THE CORRECT SEQUENCE FORMS: **I WAS AS FREE AS A BIRD.** :

   c) II-III-IV-I
   d) III-I-II-IV

   Answer: a

   c) II-I-III-IV
   d) IV-III-I-II

   Answer: a

THAT SHE POUTED AND BECAME SULLEN / THEIR ATTENTION THE CORRECT SEQUENCE FORMS: **THE CHILD WAS SO SPOILED BY HER INDULGENT PARENTS THAT SHE POUTED AND BECAME SULLEN WHEN SHE DID NOT RECEIVE ALL OF THEIR ATTENTION.** (NOTE: THE OPTIONS PROVIDED SEEM TO FOLLOW THE STRUCTURE: [II]...[I]...[IV]...[III]. THE MOST LOGICAL ORDER IS II-I-IV-III.) :
   a) II-I-IV-III
   b) III-IV-II-I
   c) I-IV-III-II
   d) II-III-IV-I

   Answer: a

   c) IV-I-II-III
   d) I-II-IV-III

   Answer: a

NALINI HAS BEEN GRANTED THE RIGHT TO COME OUT ON PAROLE TO PERFORM THE LAST RITES OF HER HUSBAND. III. S. NALINI HAS NO CHILD AND THAT IS WHY SHE IS NOT AT ALL HAPPY WITH THE SENTENCE. :

   d) All I, II and III

NALINI IS A VERY RICH WOMAN AND THAT IS WHY NO MONETARY SUPPORT IS REQUIRED TO BE GIVEN TO HER. II. S. NALINI HAS INTENTIONALLY JEOPARDIZED HER RELATIONSHIP WITH HER HUSBAND AND THAT IS WHY SHE SHOULD BE PUNISHED FOR THAT. :

   c) Both II and III
   d) Both I and III

   Answer: a

2059. WHICH AMONG THE FOLLOWING WOULD BE SIMILAR IN MEANING TO THE WORD **FERVENT** AS USED IN THE PASSAGE? :
   a) Vehement
   b) Ardent
   c) Feeling
   d) Pragmatic

   Answer: a

   b) To give the correct decision
   c) To have the same opinion
   d) To obtain suitable punishment

   Answer: a

   c) The State Government is of the opinion that the sentence given to S. Nalini can be remitted at once.
   d) The State Government wants the convict to continue with the given sentence by the court for the crime committed by her.

NALINI HAS BEEN GRANTED THE RIGHT TO COME OUT ON PAROLE TO PERFORM THE LAST RITES OF HER HUSBAND. III. S. NALINI HAS NO CHILD AND THAT IS WHY SHE IS NOT AT ALL HAPPY WITH THE SENTENCE. :
   a) Both I and II
   b) Both II and III
   c) Both I and III
   d) All I, II and III

2491. WHICH AMONG THE FOLLOWING IS/ARE CORRECT REGARDING THE OBSERVATIONS OF THE MADRAS HIGH COURT REGARDING S. NALINI? I. S. NALINI IS A VERY RICH WOMAN AND THAT IS WHY NO MONETARY SUPPORT IS REQUIRED TO BE GIVEN TO HER. II. S. NALINI IS A DREADED CRIMINAL AND THAT IS WHY SHE SHOULD BE PUT BEHIND THE BARS FOR LIFE WITH NO CHANCE AT ANY KIND OF REFORMATION. III. S. NALINI HAS INTENTIONALLY JEOPARDIZED HER RELATIONSHIP WITH HER HUSBAND AND THAT IS WHY SHE SHOULD BE PUNISHED FOR THAT. :
   a) Both I and II
   b) Both II and III
   c) Both I and III
   d) None of I, II and III

   Answer: a

2492. WHICH AMONG THE FOLLOWING WOULD BE SIMILAR IN MEANING TO THE WORD FERVENT AS USED IN THE PASSAGE? :
   a) Ardent
   b) Vehement
   c) Feeling
   d) Pragmatic

   Answer: a

2493. I. SCIENTISTS HAVE DISCOVERED II. THAT MAY PAVE WAY FOR SUSTAINABLE WAYS TO CLEAN UP OIL SPILLS III. A UNIQUE OIL-EATING BACTERIA IN THE MARIANA TRENCH, THE IV. DEEPEST PART OF THE EARTH'S OCEANS, A FINDING :
   a) II-III-IV-I
   b) I-III-IV-II
   c) IV-III-II-I
   d) III-IV-II-I

   Answer: a

2494. I. ANDHRA PRADESH ON MONDAY MORNING II. EMISAT, FROM SRIHARIKOTA IN COASTAL III. THE INDIAN SPACE RESEARCH ORGANISATION (ISRO) LAUNCHED IV. THE COUNTRY'S FIRST ELECTRONIC SURVEILLANCE SATELLITE :
   a) III-IV-II-I
   b) I-III-IV-II
   c) I-IV-III-II
   d) IV-III-II-I

   Answer: a

2495. I. CONCEPT USED WHEN II. PHILOSOPHY OF TECHNOLOGY III. TECHNOLOGICAL SOMNAMBULISM IS A IV. TALKING ABOUT THE :
   a) III-I-IV-II
   b) I-II-III-IV
   c) II-III-IV-I
   d) III-I-II-IV

   Answer: a

2496. I. WITH THE INTERIM BUDGET OUT, II. ALL EYES ARE NOW ON THE MONETARY III. POLICY COMMITTEE'S DECISION THAT IV. WILL BE ANNOUNCED ON 7 FEBRUARY :
   a) III-I-IV-II
   b) I-II-III-IV
   c) I-IV-III-II
   d) III-I-II-IV

   Answer: a

2497. I. BY SCRAPPING THE FIVE YEARS DOMESTIC II. LIBERALIZING THE RIGHT TO FLY ABROAD III. REAL ROOM FOR MANOEUVRING INVESTORS IV. FLIGHT OPERATIONS REQUIREMENT DOES NOT CREATE :
   a) II-I-III-IV
   b) II-I-IV-III
   c) IV-I-III-II
   d) IV-II-III-I

   Answer: a

   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

2755. (I) YOUR EXCEPTIONAL SKILLS IMPRESS US. (II) WE VALUE YOUR UNIQUE PERSPECTIVE. (III) YOUR SKILLS ARE IMPRESSING AND EXCEPTIONAL. :
   a) (i) and (ii) - CORRECT ANSWER
   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

2756. (I) SHE HAS GONE TO THE STORE. (II) SHE WENT TO THE STORE. (III) SHE WILL BE GOING TO THE STORE. :
   a) (i) and (ii)
   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii) - CORRECT ANSWER

   Answer: a

2757. (I) YOU SHOULD HAVE STUDIED HARDER FOR THE EXAM. (II) YOU SHOULD STUDY THE HARD EXAM. (III) YOU SHOULD STUDY FOR THE EXAM. :
   a) (i) and (ii)
   b) (i) and (iii) - CORRECT ANSWER
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

2758. (I) WE DID WENT TO THE PARK YESTERDAY. (II) WE VISITED THE PARK YESTERDAY. (III) YESTERDAY, WE VISITED THE PARK. :
   a) (i) and (ii)
   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii) - CORRECT ANSWER
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

2759. (I) HAD I KNOWN, I WOULD HAVE CALLED YOU. (II) IF I KNEW, I WOULD HAVE CALLED YOU. (III) IF I WOULD HAVE KNOWN, I WOULD HAVE CALLED YOU. :
   a) (i) only - CORRECT ANSWER (Assuming the options are (i) only, (ii) only, etc., or based on the logic that only (i) is perfectly correct, though options are given as pairs.)
   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

2760. (I) CHARLES HAS BEEN WORKING FOR FIVE HOURS. (II) CHARLES HAS WORKED FOR FIVE HOURS. (III) CHARLES IS WORKING FOR FIVE HOURS. :
   a) (i) and (ii) - CORRECT ANSWER
   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

2761. (I) TRAVELLING AROUND THE WORLD IS HIS DREAM. (II) HE WANT TO TRAVEL AROUND THE WORLD. (III) TRAVELING AROUND THE WORLD IS HIS DREAM. :
   a) (i) and (ii)
   b) (i) and (iii) - CORRECT ANSWER
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

2762. (I) I WILL FINISHED MY PROJECT TOMORROW. (II) I WILL HAVE FINISHED MY PROJECT BY TOMORROW. (III) I'LL BE DONE WITH MY PROJECT BY TOMORROW. :
   a) (i) and (ii)
   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii) - CORRECT ANSWER
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

   a) (i) and (ii)
   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii) - CORRECT ANSWER
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

2854. STUDENTS WHO ATTEMPTED THE QUESTIONS PAPER / HAVE MET SOME OF THEIR PROFESSORS, SEEKING / INFORMED ANSWERS TO THESE QUESTIONS. / NO ERROR :

   c) informed answers to these questions.
   d) No error

   Answer: a

2855. WHEN ALBERT STAYED AT THE AFRICAN JUNGLE / HE CHOSE TO PUT UP WITH MANY INCONVENIENCES SUCH AS / WILD ANIMALS AND POISONOUS INSECTS. / NO ERROR :
   a) When Albert stayed at the African jungle - CORRECT ANSWER (Should be 'in the African jungle' or 'in the African jungles')
   b) he chose to put up with many inconveniences such as
   c) wild animals and poisonous insects.
   d) No error

   Answer: a

2856. EACH ONE OF HIS SISTERS / WERE / HARDWORKING. / NO ERROR :
   a) Each one of his sisters
   b) were - CORRECT ANSWER (Should be 'was' as the subject is 'Each one')
   c) hardworking.
   d) No error

   Answer: a

   c) but is now living in Chennai.
   d) No error

   Answer: a

2858. IT HAS BEEN SHOWN THAT / VERY HIGH DOSES OF VITAMIN C ACTUALLY / CAUSES CANCER CELLS TO GROW. / NO ERROR :
   a) It has been shown that
   b) very high doses of vitamin C actually
   c) causes cancer cells to grow. - CORRECT ANSWER (Should be 'cause' as the subject 'doses' is plural)
   d) No error

   Answer: a

2859. IT IS MAINLY DUE TO PETER'S LETHARGY THAT THE PLAN FELL __________. :
   a) off
   b) through - CORRECT ANSWER (fell through means failed)
   c) in
   d) out

   Answer: a

2860. MOTHER SHALL RETURN __________ AN HOUR. :
   a) in - CORRECT ANSWER (in an hour means after the lapse of one hour)
   b) after
   c) during
   d) within

   d) abjectly

   Answer: a

   d) Vulgar

2869. I HAD NOT COMPLETED MY PROJECT SO I THOUGHT I WAS (DONE WITH) WHEN THE MANAGER ASKED ME TO HAND IT IN. :

   b) done in
   c) done on
   d) No improvement

   Answer: a

2870. ROBIN WAS UPSET AND SO (PICKED UP) HIS FOOD WHILE HIS COUSINS ATE HEARTILY. :
   a) picked out
   b) picked on
   c) picked at - CORRECT ANSWER (means to eat hesitantly or in a desultory way)
   d) No improvement

   Answer: a

2871. SERIOUS CHARGES OF CORRUPTION WERE (LEVIED AGAINST) HIM. :
   a) put
   b) levelled against - CORRECT ANSWER (The more common idiom)
   c) made
   d) No improvement

   Answer: a

2872. AS SOON AS OUR PLAN IS APPROVED, I SHALL FAVOR (ITS') ADOPTION. :
   a) it
   b) it's
   c) its - CORRECT ANSWER (Possessive adjective)
   d) No improvement

   Answer: a

2873. I PREFER REMAINING SILENT (TO) SPEAKING FALSEHOOD. :
   a) than
   b) more than
   c) rather than
   d) No improvement - CORRECT ANSWER (Prefer A to B is the correct structure)

   Answer: a

2874. TO GIVE UP A THRONE VOLUNTARILY :
   a) Archer
   b) Bigot
   c) Abdicate - CORRECT ANSWER
   d) Delegate

   Answer: a

   d) The boss had told the Secretary to bring the file that he had given to her yesterday.

2895. 1. THE MASTER RETURNED HOME AFTER SOMETIME. / 6. HE REALIZED THAT HIS DOG HAD SAVED HIS BABY. P. THE SNAKE WAS LYING DEAD UNDER THE CRADLE. Q. HE WENT INTO THE ROOM WHERE THE BABY WAS SLEEPING. R. IT HAD BEEN KILLED BY HIS DOG. S. HE NOTICED A SNAKE. :
   a) SRPQ
   b) QRPS
   c) QSPR - CORRECT ANSWER (1 -> Q -> S -> P -> R -> 6)
   d) PQRS

   Answer: a

2896. 1. ADVERSITY IS A CURSE. / 6. THIS DEVELOPS OUR LATENT POWERS, ENABLING US TO PROSPER IN LIFE. P. WHEN EVERYTHING GOES ON WELL, WE ARE TEMPTED TO TAKE MATTERS EASY. Q. BUT, IT HAS ITS USES ALSO. R. BUT ADVERSITY PROMPTS US TO EXERT OURSELVES. S. WE FALL INTO A LIFE OF COMFORT AND IDLENESS. :
   a) SPQR - CORRECT ANSWER (1 -> S -> P -> Q -> R -> 6 is the most logical flow if P and S are reversed, but SPQR is an option; 1 -> S: fall into comfort/idleness -> P: When everything goes well (cause of S) -> Q: uses also (contrast) -> R: prompts us to exert (key use) -> 6: develops powers.)
   b) PRQS
   c) QRSP
   d) QSRP

   Answer: a

2897. 1. A TRAVELLER HAD SPENT MANY A YEAR IN AFRICA. / 6. "I RAN, AND THEY RAN AFTER ME!" P. "HOW DID YOU MANAGE IT?" ASKED ONE OF HIS FRIENDS, GREATLY IMPRESSED. Q. ON HIS RETURN HOME, HE NARRATED HIS ADVENTURES TO HIS FRIENDS. R. "OH, IT WAS NOTHING", REPLIED THE TRAVELLER. S. "WHEN I WAS IN EL DOAB", HE SAID, "I MADE FIFTY ARABS RUN!" :
   a) RPQS
   b) QRSP
   c) QSPR - CORRECT ANSWER (1 -> Q: narrated -> S: told the story -> P: friend asked -> R: traveller replied -> 6: punchline)
   d) PQSR

   Answer: a

2898. 1. WE WANTED TO RELAX AND HAVE FUN. / 6. WE ENJOYED OURSELVES A LOT AND FELT A WELCOME CHANGE IN OUR MONOTONOUS LIFE. P. ALL OF US AGREED TO SHARE RESPONSIBILITIES. Q. TWO OF US TOOK OUR CARS. R. WE DECIDED TO GO FOR A PICNIC TO GOLF LINKS. S. EACH ONE OF US BROUGHT ONE DISH, SOME FRUITS AND SWEETS. :
   a) QSPR
   b) PRQS
   c) RPQS - CORRECT ANSWER (1 -> R: decided -> P: agreed to share -> Q: took cars -> S: brought food -> 6: enjoyed)
   d) SRPQ

   Answer: a

2899. A STATE OF DECADENCE HAS COME ABOUT BECAUSE OF :

   c) natural disasters
   d) None of the above - CORRECT ANSWER (The text specifies "indiscriminate industrialization")

2989. (I) SHE IS TOO PROUD TO ASK ANYONE TO HELP HER. (II) SHE IS SO PROUD THAT SHE WILL NOT ASK ANYONE TO HELP HER. (III) SHE IS TOO PROUD TO ASK. :

   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

2990. (I) THIS BOX IS SO HEAVY THAT IT CANNOT BE LIFTED. (II) THIS BOX IS HEAVY CANNOT BE LIFTED. (III) THIS BOX IS TOO HEAVY TO LIFT. :
   a) (i) and (ii)
   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: b

2991. (I) NO MISTAKES WERE MADE. (II) WE ACCEPT OUR MISTAKES. (III) WE ACCEPT THE MISTAKES WE HAVE MADE. :
   a) (i) and (ii)
   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: d

2992. (I) WALKING ALWAYS MADE HIM TIRED. (II) HE FEELS LIKE WALKING WHENEVER HE IS TIRED. (III) HE IS ALWAYS TIRED WHEN HE IS WALKING. :
   a) (i) and (ii)
   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: b

2993. (I) SHE COULD NOT ATTEND THE WEDDING AS SHE WAS ILL. (II) SHE COULD NOT ATTEND THE WEDDING ON ACCOUNT OF HER ILLNESS. (III) SHE COULD NOT BE ILL TO ATTEND THE WEDDING. :
   a) (i) and (ii)
   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

3224. WHAT IS ONE OF THE PRIMARY ECOLOGICAL ROLES OF THE AMAZON RAINFOREST? :

   d) Acting as a barrier against natural disasters

   Answer: b

   a) Fishing and tourism
   b) Cattle ranching and soybean farming
   c) Urban development and water pollution
   d) Hunting and road construction

   Answer: b

3226. WHAT HAPPENS WHEN TREES IN THE AMAZON ARE CUT DOWN? :
   a) The oxygen levels in the atmosphere increase
   b) Carbon stored in the trees is released into the atmosphere
   c) The soil becomes more fertile for agriculture
   d) Wildlife population increases due to habitat expansion

   Answer: b

   d) Relocating indigenous communities

   d) No error

3403. I AM TIRED AS I AM WORKING SINCE 7 O'CLOCK IN THE MORNING. :
   a) I was working
   b) I have been working
   c) I had been working
   d) No error

   Answer: b

3404. SHEELA TOLD HER TEACHER TO EXPLAIN THE CHAPTER ONCE AGAIN. :
   a) ordered her teacher
   b) said to her teacher
   c) asked her teacher
   d) No error

   Answer: c

   a) write
   b) written
   c) will write
   d) No error

   Answer: b

   b) pick
   c) plucking
   d) No error

   Answer: c

   b) like

   d) and

   Answer: a

   b) in
   c) behind
   d) nearby

   Answer: c

   b) upon
   c) on
   d) at

   Answer: a

   b) with

   d) by

   b) when

   Answer: d

   d) by

   b) for
   c) from
   d) with

   Answer: b

3414. THE MAN EXCLAIMED THAT HIS WALLET WAS STOLEN. (INDIRECT) :
   a) "My wallet was stolen !" the man said.
   b) "Somebody stole my wallet !" exclaimed the man.
   c) The man exclaimed, "My wallet was stolen !"
   d) The man cried, "My wallet was stolen."

   Answer: c

3415. RIMA SAID TO PRIYA, "WHY ARE YOU SKETCHING ON THE WALL?" (DIRECT) :
   a) Rima asked Priya why was she sketching on the wall.
   b) Rima asked Priya why had she been sketching on the wall.
   c) Rima asked Priya that why is she sketching on the wall.
   d) Rima asked Priya why she was sketching on the wall.

   Answer: d

3416. "STAND AT EASE", THE SOLDIER SAID TO HIS MEN. (DIRECT) :
   a) The soldier told his men that they should stand at ease.
   b) The soldier said to his men that they should stand at ease.
   c) The soldier urged his men to stand at ease.
   d) The soldier commanded his men to stand at ease.

   Answer: d

3417. MR. SWER ASKED THE LADY IF SHE COULD TELL HIM WHERE THE NEAREST POST OFFICE IS. (INDIRECT) :
   a) "Where is the nearest post office?" Mr. Swer asked the lady.
   b) Mr. Swer asked the lady, "Could you tell me where the nearest post office is?"
   c) Mr. Swer asked the lady, "Where is the nearest post office?"
   d) Mr. Swer said to the lady, "Where is the nearest post office?"

   Answer: b

3418. THE PROFESSOR SAID THAT NOBODY COULD SOLVE THE PROBLEM. (INDIRECT) :
   a) The Professor said, "Nobody can solve the problem."
   b) The Professor said, "Nobody could solve the problem."
   c) The Professor exclaimed, "Nobody could solve the problem."
   d) The Professor exclaimed, "Nobody can solve the problem."

   Answer: b

3419. SEETA SAID TO ME, "CAN YOU GIVE ME YOUR PEN?" (DIRECT) :
   a) Seeta asked me can I give her my pen.
   b) Seeta asked me if I can give me your pen.
   c) Seeta asked me if I could give her my pen.
   d) Seeta asked me if I could give me your pen.

   Answer: c

3420. THE FATHER WARNED HIS SON THAT HE SHOULD BEWARE OF THE PICKPOCKET. (INDIRECT) :
   a) The father warned his son, "Beware of the pickpocket !"
   b) The father warned his son, "Watch that chap!"
   c) The father warned his son, "Be careful about the pickpocket."
   d) The father warned his son, "Don't fall into the trap."

   Answer: a

   b) He proposed going for a swim as it was quite fine.
   c) He suggested going for a swim as it was quite fine.
   d) He advised me to go for a swim as it was quite fine.

   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

3524. (I) I'VE NEVER SEEN A TIGER AT CLOSE RANGE. (II) I'VE NEVER SEEN A TIGER THIS CLOSE. (III) I'VE NEVER SEEN A TIGER CLOSE UP. :
   a) (i) and (ii)
   b) (ii) and (iii)
   c) (i) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

3525. (I) SHE'S A FAMOUS ACTRESS OF THE YESTERYEARS. (II) SHE'S A FAMOUS ACTRESS YESTERDAY. (III) SHE WAS ONCE A FAMOUS ACTRESS. :
   a) (i) and (ii)
   b) (ii) and (iii)
   c) (i) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

   a) (i) and (iii)
   b) (i) and (ii)
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

3604. I HAVEN'T HAD FUN IN AGES. I HAVE _________ RIGHT NOW. (NOTE: THIS SENTENCE IS INCOMPLETE OR PHRASED AWKWARDLY FOR THE GIVEN OPTIONS, AS THE OPTIONS DO NOT LOGICALLY COMPLETE "I HAVE... RIGHT NOW" TO MEAN "I'M HAVING FUN." HOWEVER, ASSUMING THE INTENT IS TO SAY 'I HAVE TOO MUCH ON MY PLATE' MEANING I'M BUSY/STRESSED/NOT HAVING FUN, OR IF IT'S MEANT TO BE SOMETHING LIKE 'I NEED TO LET LOOSE RIGHT NOW,' LET'S CHECK THE OPTIONS. NONE FIT PERFECTLY FOR 'FUN', BUT FOR A FILL-IN-THE-BLANK QUESTION, WE RE-EVALUATE THE QUESTION AND OPTIONS. IF THE INTENDED SENTENCE WAS "I HAVEN'T HAD FUN IN AGES. I CAN'T HAVE FUN RIGHT NOW BECAUSE I HAVE _________", THEN 'TOO MUCH ON MY PLATE' WOULD FIT. SINCE WE MUST CHOOSE THE *CORRECT* OPTION FROM THE PROVIDED TEXT, AND THE PRECEDING SENTENCE IS A STATEMENT OF PAST LACK OF FUN, THE CURRENT SENTENCE IS EXPECTED TO RELATE. OPTION (C) 'TOO MUCH ON MY PLATE' (MEANING TOO MANY RESPONSIBILITIES) CONTRASTS WITH THE IDEA OF HAVING FUN, WHICH MIGHT BE THE INTENDED MEANING FOR A TEST-TAKER'S CHALLENGE, EVEN IF THE FLOW IS SLIGHTLY ODD. IF THE SENTENCE WAS 'I MUST HAVE FUN RIGHT NOW, I'M GOING TO...', THE OPTIONS STILL DON'T FIT. GIVEN THE CONSTRAINTS, SELECTING THE MOST LIKELY INTENDED ANSWER IN AN EXAM CONTEXT THAT OFTEN USES CONTRAST/REASON IS NEEDED. LET'S ASSUME THE QUESTION HAS A TYPO AND SHOULD IMPLY A REASON FOR NOT HAVING FUN, MAKING (C) THE MOST PLAUSIBLE CHOICE.) :
   a) two for the price of one
   b) done all in a day's work
   c) too much on my plate
   d) been hit by the weather

   Answer: c

3605. AFTER WINNING THE CONTEST, SHE WOULDN'T TALK TO ORDINARY MORTALS LIKE US. SHE NOW WALKS WITH HER _________. :
   a) head over heels
   b) head in the cloud (Correct idiom is 'head in the clouds')
   c) out of her head
   d) turn up

   Answer: b

3606. HE WATCHED _________ AS THE WATER SWEPT AWAY HIS CAR. :

   d) No error

   d) have finish

3940. NOW I HAVE NO WORK, **DO I**? (THE QUESTION TAG FOR 'NO WORK' IS POSITIVE, AND 'HAVE' IS OFTEN TREATED AS A MAIN VERB, OR 'DO' IS USED TO FORM THE TAG FOR THE NEGATIVE IMPLIED BY 'NO WORK'.) (SELECTING 'DO I' AS COMMON USAGE FOR A TAG QUESTION FROM A STATEMENT IMPLYING 'I DON'T HAVE WORK') :
   a) am I
   b) do I (Answer - "I have no work" is equivalent to "I don't have work," for which the tag is "do I")
   c) shall I
   d) have I

   Answer: a

3941. LET US PLAY TOGETHER, **SHALL WE**? (STANDARD QUESTION TAG FOR 'LET'S/LET US') :
   a) will we
   b) shall we (Answer)
   c) are we
   d) do we

   Answer: a

3942. SHE WAS SINGING **A** SONG. :
   a) an
   b) the
   c) a (Answer)
   d) those

   Answer: a

3943. YOU ARE GUILTY **OF** THEFT. :
   a) by
   b) of (Answer)
   c) in
   d) to

   Answer: a

3944. THEY HOLD HIM **IN** HIGH ESTEEM. :
   a) at
   b) of
   c) for
   d) in (Answer)

   Answer: a

3945. TRY TO GET RID **OF** THE PROBLEM. :
   a) of (Answer)
   b) on
   c) with
   d) in

   Answer: a

3946. I AM NOT MOVED **BY** YOUR ENTREATIES. :
   a) for
   b) in
   c) by (Answer)
   d) about

   Answer: a

   a) with
   b) for
   c) of
   d) about (Answer)

   Answer: a

   b) of (Answer)

   d) to

   b) encyclopedia (Answer)
   c) monolith
   d) kindle

   Answer: a

3973. I) THAT STUDENT IS ALWAYS LATE. II) HE IS THE STUDENT WHO ALWAYS ARRIVES LATE. III) HE IS THE STUDENT WHO IS ALWAYS LATE IN ARRIVING. :
   a) (i) and (ii) (Answer - i and ii are grammatically standard; iii is wordy but technically acceptable, but typically (i) and (ii) are considered the most correct/natural.)

   Answer: a

3974. I) SAUDI ARABIA IS A COUNTRY WHICH EXPORTS OIL ALL OVER THE WORLD. II) THE WHOLE WORLD IMPORTS OIL FROM SAUDI ARABIA III) OIL EXPORTS SAUDI ARABIA TO THE WHOLE WORLD. :
   a) (i) and (ii) (Answer - iii uses 'exports' incorrectly; i and ii are correct statements.)

   Answer: a

3975. I) I TOLD HIM THE NEWS. II) I GAVE HIM THE NEWS. III) I GIVEN THE NEWS TO HIM. :
   a) (i) and (ii) (Answer - iii uses the incorrect past participle 'given' without a helping verb.)

   Answer: a

3976. I) THEY DO NOT WANT TO GO BY THEIRSELVES. II) THEY DO NOT WANT TO GO BY THEMSELVES. III) THEY DO NOT WANT TO GO. :
   c) (ii) and (iii) (Answer - 'by theirselves' (i) is not standard English; 'themselves' (ii) and (iii) are correct.)

   Answer: a

3977. I) THE CHILD IS GETTING READY FOR SCHOOL. II) THE CHILD WILL TAKE A BUS TO SCHOOL. III) THE CHILD WILL TAKE THE SCHOOL BY BUS. :
   a) (i) and (ii) (Answer - i and ii are grammatically correct; iii is nonsensical.)

   Answer: a

3978. I) THE NEW SUIT COST ME OVER FORTY DOLLARS. II) THE NEW SUIT COST OVER FORTY DOLLARS TO ME. III) THE NEW SUIT THAT I BOUGHT COST ME FORTY DOLLARS. :
   b) (i) and (iii) (Answer - i is the most natural, standard way to use 'cost'; iii is also correct and complete; ii is awkward/incorrect usage of 'to me' with 'cost'.)

   Answer: a

3979. I) THAT MOUNT EVEREST IS THE HIGHEST PEAK IN THE WORLD. II) I KNOW THAT MOUNT EVEREST IS THE HIGHEST PEAK IN THE WORLD. III) MOUNT EVEREST IS THE HIGHEST PEAK IN THE WORLD. :
   c) (ii) and (iii) (Answer - i is a dependent clause lacking a main clause/verb; ii and iii are complete, correct sentences.)

   Answer: a

3980. I) WHOSE BOOKS ARE THESE? II) WHOSE BOOKS IS THESE? III) WHOSE BOOK IS THIS? :
   b) (i) and (iii) (Answer - i and iii correctly match the plural subject/verb/pronoun and singular subject/verb/pronoun respectively; ii has a plural subject and singular verb.)

   Answer: a

3981. I) WE VISITED THE BUILDING WHICH IS FAMOUS FOR ITS UNUSUAL DESIGN II) WE VISITED THE BUILDING WHAT IS FAMOUS FOR ITS UNUSUAL DESIGN III) WE VISITED THE BUILDING THAT IS FAMOUS FOR ITS UNUSUAL DESIGN :
   b) (i) and (iii) (Answer - 'which' (i) and 'that' (iii) are correct relative pronouns; 'what' (ii) is incorrect here.)

   Answer: a

3982. I) MY FATHER OFTEN GIVES ME A GIFT. II) MY FATHER OFTEN GIVES A GIFT TO ME. III) I OFTEN GET A GIFT FROM MY FATHER. :
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii) (Answer - All three sentences are grammatically correct and convey essentially the same meaning.)

   Answer: a

3983. SAM WAS THE FIRST (A) / PERSON WHO CONGRATULATE (B)/ME ON MY SUCCESS (C)/NO ERROR (D) [CITE_START]ANSWER: (B) - SHOULD BE "WHO CONGRATULATED" [CITE: 288] :

   b) to be sure

   Answer: a

4130. DOESN'T THE CAT WANT _______ MILK? :
   a) some (Answer - Used in an anticipated positive response or a request/offer)
   b) many
   c) too many
   d) little

   Answer: a

4131. I AM NOT AS _______ AS YOU. :
   a) kind (Answer - Correct structure is "as + adjective + as")
   b) kinder
   c) kindest
   d) most kind

   Answer: a

4132. I HAVE _______ THINGS TO DO. :
   a) so much
   b) very little
   c) too many
   d) a lot (Answer - The best general fit for plural countable noun 'things')

   Answer: a

4133. HE LOOKS _______ HIS GRANDMOTHER. :
   a) as
   b) by
   c) like (Answer - Correct phrasal verb for similarity)
   d) same

   Answer: a

4134. IT WAS _______ TO CATCH THE PLANE. :
   a) late
   b) so late
   c) very late
   d) too late (Answer - Implies excessive lateness, preventing the action)

   Answer: a

4135. LYDIA IS _______ IN OUR GROUP ABOUT EXAM RESULTS. :
   a) the more nervous
   b) the most nervous (Answer - Superlative degree indicated by "in our group")
   c) not as nervous as
   d) as nervous as

   Answer: a

4136. TED WISHES THAT HE _______ HIS JOB LAST MONTH. :
   a) have not lost
   b) is not losing
   c) had not lost (Answer - Past unreal condition/wish uses Past Perfect)
   d) were not lost

   Answer: a

4137. I AM OPPOSED TO _______ TO WAR. :
   a) be gone
   b) be going
   c) have been gone
   d) going (Answer - "Opposed to" is followed by a gerund)

   Answer: a

4138. YOUR FATHER IS A TEACHER, _______? :
   a) isn't it
   b) isn't he (Answer - Correct question tag for the subject 'father')
   c) wasn't it
   d) was it not

   Answer: a

4139. HE REFUSED _______ MY PLEA. :
   a) considering
   b) having to consider
   c) consideration
   d) to consider (Answer - The verb 'refuse' takes the infinitive)

   Answer: a

4140. HE HAS BEEN **ELIMINATED** FROM THE CHESS TOURNAMENT. :
   a) ousted (Answer - Meaning expelled or driven out)
   b) killed
   c) accepted
   d) promoted

   Answer: a

4141. I WOULD LIKE TO **DISPEL** HER SORROW. :
   a) increase
   b) extend
   c) lighten (Answer - Meaning alleviate or reduce)
   d) move

   Answer: a

4142. HE DOES NOT KNOW HOW TO **INTERACT** WITH PEOPLE. :

   b) socialise
   c) communicate (Answer - Means share thoughts or feelings, a key part of interaction)
   d) reject

   Answer: a

   d) meaningless

   Answer: a

   Answer: a

   d) wrong

   Answer: a

4150. THE MAN STEPPED _______ THE PLATFORM. :

   b) into

4202. (I) WE SPENT THE HOLIDAYS IN A COTTAGE IN THE MOUNTAINS. (II) WE SPENT THE HOLIDAYS IN A SMALL COTTAGE, RENTED FROM A FRIEND IN THE MOUNTAINS. (III) WE SPENT THE HOLIDAYS IN THE MOUNTAINS, IN A SMALL COTTAGE WE RENTED FROM A FRIEND. :
   a) (i) & (ii)
   c) (ii) & (iii)
   b) (i) & (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) & (iii)

   Answer: a

4203. (I) HE ANNOUNCED HIS RETIREMENT FROM THE CIVIL SERVICE. (II) HE ANNOUNCED THAT HE WAS RETIRING FROM CIVIL SERVICE. (III) HE ANNOUNCED THAT HE WAS RETIRING FROM THE CIVIL SERVICE. :
   a) (i) & (ii)
   c) (ii) & (iii)
   b) (i) & (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) & (iii)

   Answer: a

4204. (I) WHAT AN OPPORTUNITY YOU HAVE MISSED! (II) WHAT AN OPPORTUNITY YOU MISSED! (III) WHAT OPPORTUNITY YOU MISSED! :
   a) (i) & (ii)
   c) (ii) & (iii)
   b) (i) & (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) & (iii)

   Answer: a

4205. (I) HE PICKED UP THE BALL QUITE QUICKLY. (II) HE PICKED UP THE BALL QUICKLY. (III) HE QUICKLY PICKED THE BALL. :
   a) (i) & (ii)
   c) (ii) & (iii)
   b) (i) & (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) & (iii)

   Answer: a

4206. (I) HER HUSBAND GAVE THE NECKLACE ON THEIR WEDDING DAY. (II) HER HUSBAND GAVE HER A NECKLACE ON THEIR WEDDING DAY. (III) HER HUSBAND GAVE HER THE NECKLACE ON THEIR WEDDING DAY. :
   a) (i) & (ii)
   c) (ii) & (iii)
   b) (i) & (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) & (iii)

   Answer: a

4207. (I) I HAVE NOT SEEN HIM SINCE LAST JANUARY. (II) I DID NOT SEE HIM SINCE LAST JANUARY. (III) I HAVE NOT SEEN HIM SINCE JANUARY. :
   a) (i) & (ii)
   c) (ii) & (iii)
   b) (i) & (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) & (iii)

   Answer: a

4208. (I) A TERRORIST GOT KILLED IN AN ENCOUNTER. (II) A TERRORIST WAS KILLED IN AN ENCOUNTER. (III) A TERRORIST HAS BEEN KILLED IN AN ENCOUNTER. :
   a) (i) & (ii)
   c) (ii) & (iii)
   b) (i) & (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) & (iii)

   Answer: a

4209. (I) I TOLD HIM, HONESTY IS THE BEST POLICY. (II) I TOLD HIM THAT HONESTY IS THE BEST POLICY. (III) I TOLD HIM THAT HONESTY WAS THE BEST POLICY. :
   a) (i) & (ii)
   c) (ii) & (iii)
   b) (i) & (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) & (iii)

   Answer: a

4210. (I) I SWITCHED ON THE TELEVISION. THERE WERE NO INTERESTING PROGRAMMES ON. (II) I SWITCHED ON THE TELEVISION BUT THERE WERE NO INTERESTING PROGRAMMES ON. (III) I SWITCHED ON THE TELEVISION AND THERE WERE NO INTERESTING PROGRAMMES ON. :
   a) (i) & (ii)
   c) (ii) & (iii)
   b) (i) & (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) & (iii)

   Answer: a

4211. (I) I HAVE DECIDED TO SELL SEVERAL OF MY FURNITURE. (II) I HAVE DECIDED TO SELL MY FURNITURE. (III) I HAVE DECIDED TO SELL SOME OF MY FURNITURE. :

   d) Donbok
   a) DCAB
   b) CBAD
   c) DCAB
   d) BDCA

   Answer: d

4496. THE/NIGHTFALL / THEIR HOOTING CALLS AT / OWLS BEGAN / :
   a) the
   b) nightfall
   c) their hooting calls at
   d) owls began
   a) DCAB
   c) ABCD
   b) ADCB
   d) DCBA

   Answer: d

4497. _________ HAVE BEEN TO THE FOOTBALL MATCH. :
   a) neither Andy nor I
   b) neither I nor Andy
   c) neither Andy nor me
   d) neither me nor Andy gives

   Answer: a

   c) strolled
   b) was strolling
   d) has strolled

   Answer: b

   b) between me and you
   c) between I and you
   d) between you and me

   Answer: c

4610. THERE WASN'T NO BUS SERVICE (A)/ TOMORROW BECAUSE OF (B)/ THE UNION STRIKE (C)/ NO ERROR (D). :

   b) B
   c) C
   d) D

   Answer: a

   a) A
   b) B
   c) C
   d) D

   Answer: a

   a) A
   b) B
   c) C
   d) D

   Answer: a

4613. ONE WHO HAS A SPECIAL SKILL IN JUDGING ART, MUSIC, ETC :
   a) epicure
   b) iconoclast
   c) connoisseur
   d) antiquarian

   Answer: a

4614. ONE WHO WALKS IN ONE'S SLEEP :
   a) somnambulist
   b) mimic
   c) teetotaler
   d) kleptomaniac

   Answer: a

4615. ONE WHO KNOWS MANY LANGUAGES :
   a) versatile
   b) oculist
   c) polyglot
   d) philatelist

   Answer: a

4616. A NUMBER OF STARS GROUPED TOGETHER :
   a) astronomy
   b) galaxy
   c) fleet
   d) constellation

   Answer: a

4617. THE SUCCESS OF THE DEPARTMENT IS THE RESULT OF THE EFFORTS OF HIS PREDECESSOR. :
   a) progenitor
   b) precursor
   c) forerunner
   d) descendant (Answer: opposite of 'predecessor' is 'descendant' or 'successor', 'descendant' is the best choice among options for Antonym)

   Answer: a

4618. THE ARID SOIL IS UNSUITABLE FOR AGRICULTURAL PURPOSES. :
   a) barren
   b) fertile (Answer: opposite of 'arid' (dry/barren) is 'fertile')
   c) dry
   d) sterile

   Answer: a

4619. THE TROPICAL WEATHER OF THE PLAINS SUITED HER. :
   a) torrid
   b) humid
   c) hot
   d) arctic (Answer: opposite of 'tropical' (hot/humid) is 'arctic' (extremely cold))

   Answer: a

4620. HIS KIND DEEDS WHICH WENT UNNOTICED MADE HIM AN UNSUNG HERO. :
   a) nameless
   b) celebrated (Answer: opposite of 'unsung' (uncelebrated) is 'celebrated')
   c) anonymous
   d) noble

   Answer: a

4621. THE ZEALOUS ATTITUDE OF THE SPORTSMAN MADE HIM POPULAR. :
   a) indifferent (Answer: opposite of 'zealous' (enthusiastic/eager) is 'indifferent')
   b) distasteful
   c) enthusiastic
   d) feverish

   Answer: a

4622. THE THIEVES HOPED ________ THEIR CRIME. :
   a) to get away with (Answer: correct idiom for escaping punishment)
   b) to get away from
   c) to flee off
   d) to escape from

   Answer: a

4623. EITHER THE CHILDREN OR THE HELPER ________ THE CORRIDOR. :
   a) sweep
   b) sweeps (Answer: with 'Either...or', the verb agrees with the closer subject, 'helper' is singular)
   c) will sweep
   d) will be sweeping

   Answer: a

4624. WE WILL NOT BEGIN THE WORK ________ CONDITIONS. :
   a) until they have agreed to
   b) unless they have agreed with (Answer: 'agreed to' is for terms/conditions, 'agreed with' is for a person/opinion. 'Unless' is the correct conjunction here.)
   c) lest they agree to
   d) till they have agreed with

   Answer: a

4625. WE HAVE ENDURED HIS TYRANNY ________ :
   a) since three years ago
   b) for three years now (Answer: correct use of 'for' with present perfect to indicate duration up to the present)
   c) for three years long
   d) three years

   Answer: a

4626. HE ________ OUR NOVEL FOR THE LAST TWO YEARS, BUT HE HAS NOT FINISHED IT YET. :
   a) wrote
   b) is writing
   c) writes
   d) has been writing (Answer: 'has been writing' (Present Perfect Continuous) is correct for an action that started in the past and is still ongoing)

   Answer: a

4627. WE ARE MUCH STRONGER THAN ________ AT FOOTBALL. :
   a) they
   b) those
   c) them
   d) they are (Answer: Comparison of subjects requires 'they are' or just 'they' which stands for 'they are'. 'They are' is clearer and grammatically complete.)

   Answer: a

4628. ________ DID YOU MEET IN THE PARK YESTERDAY? :
   a) whom
   b) who (Answer: 'Who' is correct as the subject of the question, or 'Whom' if it were strictly the object, but 'Who' is now widely accepted in common speech/writing when it is the first word.)
   c) what
   d) where

   Answer: a

4629. NEITHER JAKE ________ JOSE SEEMS TO BE CAPABLE OF DOING THIS. :
   a) or
   b) and
   c) but
   d) nor (Answer: 'Neither' pairs with 'nor')

   Answer: a

4630. HE SHALL BE DISMISSED FOR ________ :
   a) neglecting duty
   b) negligence of duty (Answer: most formal and correct noun phrase for the reason of dismissal)
   c) neglecting his duties
   d) negligence of all duty

   Answer: a

4631. MANGOES ________ SHOULD BE THROWN AWAY. :
   a) that are over ripe (Answer: 'Mangoes' is plural, needs 'that are')
   b) that have over ripe
   c) which are over ripe
   d) which is over ripe

   Answer: a

4632. ________ BEING A PAINTER, ROSSETTI WAS ALSO A POET. :
   a) along with
   b) besides (Answer: 'besides' means 'in addition to')
   c) apart from
   d) inspite of

   Answer: a

4633. A BRICK HAS FALLEN ________ THE WELL. :
   a) inside
   b) off
   c) in
   d) into (Answer: 'into' indicates movement from outside to inside)

   Answer: a

4634. THE STREAM RAN ________ A LITTLE TUNNEL. :
   a) through (Answer: 'through' indicates movement from one end to the other inside a space)
   b) from
   c) inside
   d) into

   Answer: a

4635. HOLD IT CAREFULLY ________ YOUR THUMB AND FOREFINGER. :
   a) with (Answer: indicating the instrument used for holding)
   b) between
   c) in
   d) within

   Answer: a

4636. HE HID A BANKNOTE ________ THE PAGES OF A NOVEL OF DICKENS. :
   a) within (Answer: 'within' often means "inside the bounds of" or more deeply/completely inside)
   b) inside
   c) between
   d) in

   Answer: a

4637. IF YOU HAPPEN TO COME ________ MY LOST PAPERS, PLEASE LET ME KNOW. :
   a) through
   b) across (Answer: 'come across' means to find by chance)
   c) by
   d) over

   Answer: a

4638. LEAN IT ________ THE WALL IF YOU DON'T WANT IT TO FALL. :
   a) at
   b) in
   c) over
   d) on (Answer: 'lean on' or 'lean against' is correct, 'on' is the best fit here)

   Answer: a

4639. HER BEAUTIFUL VOICE COMPENSATES ________ HER SHORT STATURE. :
   a) with
   b) by
   c) at
   d) for (Answer: 'compensates for' is the correct phrasal verb)

   Answer: a

4640. CAN I DEPEND ________ YOU NOT TO BE ANGRY WITH ME FOR BEING LATE? :
   a) on
   b) upon
   c) in
   d) for

   Answer: a

4641. LET ME ASSURE YOU ________ MY HONEST INTENTIONS. :
   a) of (Answer: 'assure someone of something' is the correct structure)
   b) about
   c) with
   d) for

   Answer: a

4642. SCHOOL OF THOUGHT :
   a) a way of thinking that is opposed by many
   b) a way of thinking that a number of people share (Answer)
   c) a way of thinking that is imposed on everyone
   d) a way of thinking that is shared by a few

   Answer: a

4643. LAMB TO THE SLAUGHTER :
   a) a dangerous act that causes serious threat
   b) the act of being lead to a slaughter house
   c) someone who is going to do something dangerous without realising it (Answer: someone innocent and defenseless being led into a dangerous or hopeless situation)
   d) useless sacrifice and violence

   Answer: a

4644. FIGHT A LOSING BATTLE :
   a) a struggle that appears to be successful only for a while
   b) to fight only for the sake of fighting
   c) to try to do something that you'll probably never succeed in doing (Answer)
   d) to fight with the same tactics of the opponent

   Answer: a

4645. IN THE FITNESS OF TIME :
   a) a time that is not bound by routine
   b) a time that is accurate as clockwork
   c) at the predestined or right time (Answer: the phrase is 'in the fitness of **things**' meaning 'at the right/appropriate moment')
   d) a time that is leisurely

   Answer: a

4646. HAVE A WOLF INSIDE THE STOMACH :
   a) to be very hungry (Answer: meaning to have an intense appetite)
   b) to have a bad stomach upset
   c) to have a craving for a particular food
   d) to give a false alarm

   Answer: a

4647. TO DARKEN ONE'S DOOR :
   a) to visit
   b) to paint an entrance black
   c) a visit that is unpleasant
   d) a visit that is unwelcome (Answer: to visit, especially when unwanted or in a way that causes trouble)

   Answer: a

4648. NOT GET TO FIRST BASE :
   a) to fail to make a successful start (Answer: based on baseball, meaning to fail to progress past the very first stage)
   b) to fail at the negotiating table
   c) to fail to strike oil
   d) to fail to create an impression

   Answer: a

4649. LIGHT AT THE END OF THE TUNNEL :
   a) a faint light indicating correct direction
   b) something that encourages
   c) something that shows one is nearly at the end of a difficult situation (Answer: an indication that a difficult period is almost over)
   d) a flash of light in the dark causing one to heave a sigh of relief

   Answer: a

4650. RANT AND RAVE :
   a) a long angry speech that is unpleasant
   b) to show one's anger by shouting or complaining loudly for a long time (Answer: to talk loudly and angrily, often for a long time)
   c) to protest loudly in public
   d) to shout aloud in order to catch somebody's attention

   Answer: a

4651. TO GO THROUGH THE ROOF :
   a) to rise or increase very quickly (Answer: used for prices, expenses, or anger, meaning to increase or become angry rapidly and extremely)
   b) a temper that shoots instantly
   c) a rise or increase of something that is gradual
   d) a quick rise of something that soon comes down again

   Answer: a

4652. HER DOCILE MANNERS WON THE HEARTS OF MANY :
   a) compliant (Answer: 'docile' means ready to accept control or instruction; submissive/compliant)
   b) wilful
   c) generous
   d) brazen

   Answer: a

4653. THE CAPITAL CITY WAS THE CENTRE, ATTRACTING MANY TOURISTS :
   a) periphery
   b) concentre
   c) edge
   d) nucleus (Answer: 'nucleus' means the central and most important part)

   Answer: a

4654. HIS FOOLHARDY NATURE WAS A CAUSE OF GREAT WORRY. :
   a) moronic
   b) jovial
   c) impulsive (Answer: 'foolhardy' means recklessly bold or rash, which can be synonymous with being impulsive)
   d) mischievous

   Answer: a

4655. I COULD NOT STOP ADMIRING THE LUSTRE OF THE NEW TABLE. :
   a) robust
   b) design
   c) sheen (Answer: 'lustre' means a gentle sheen or soft glow)
   d) carvings

   Answer: a

4656. THE AUDIENCE LISTENED TO THE MAYOR'S SPEECH WITH RAPT ATTENTION. :
   a) delighted
   b) uninterested
   c) intent (Answer: 'rapt' means completely engrossed or absorbed, i.e., intent)
   d) confounded

   Answer: a

4657. INSPITE OF HIS ADVANCED AGE HE WAS STILL SPRIGHTLY. :
   a) sluggish
   b) motivated
   c) active (Answer: 'sprightly' means lively; full of energy; active)
   d) inactive

   Answer: a

4658. THE TEMPERAMENTAL NATURE OF THE OFFICER AFFECTED HIS SUBORDINATES. :
   a) stable
   b) calm
   c) erratic (Answer: 'temperamental' means subject to sudden and unpredictable changes of mood, i.e., erratic)
   d) upheaval

   Answer: a

4659. THE ENTIRE TOWN WAS OBLITERATED BY THE MIGHTY ARMY. :
   a) wiped out (Answer: 'obliterated' means to destroy completely; wipe out)
   b) deleted
   c) founded
   d) cancelled

   Answer: a

4660. THE ELOQUENCE OF THE SPEAKER REVEALED HIS WISDOM. :
   a) erudition
   b) articulateness (Answer: 'eloquence' means fluent or persuasive speaking, i.e., articulateness)
   c) inarticulateness
   d) elucidation

   Answer: a

4661. THE TERTIARY SECTOR OF THE ECONOMY COMPRISES INDUSTRY THAT DEALS WITH SERVICES. :
   a) third in rank or importance (Answer: 'tertiary' means third in order or level)
   b) most significant in rank or importance
   c) foremost in rank or importance
   d) last in rank or importance

   Answer: a

4662. IN LESS THAN NO TIME :
   a) instantly
   b) slowly
   c) never
   d) gradually

   Answer: a

4663. LICK ONE'S WOUNDS. :

   d) (i), (ii) & (iii)

   Answer: a

4906. (I) EXCEPT FOR THE ROSES, WHICH ARE FOREIGN, ALL OTHER PLANTS IN MY GARDEN ARE INDIGENOUS. (II) EXCEPT FOR THE ROSES, WHICH ARE FOREIGN, ALL OTHER PLANTS IN THE GARDEN ARE INDIGENOUS. (III) EXCEPT FOR THE ROSES, WHICH ARE FOREIGN, ALL OTHER PLANTS IN THE GARDEN IS INDIGENOUS. :
   a) (i) & (ii)
   b) (i) & (iii)
   c) (ii) & (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) & (iii)

   Answer: a

   c) Play by the ear
   d) Black out

   Answer: a

5191. THE MAN EXCLAIMED THAT HIS WALLET WAS STOLEN. :
   a) "My wallet was stolen!" the man said.
   b) "Somebody stole my wallet!" exclaimed the man.
   c) The man exclaimed, "My wallet was stolen!"
   d) The man cried, "My wallet was stolen."

   Answer: a

5192. SOCRATES SAID, "VIRTUE IS ITS OWN REWARD." :
   a) Socrates said that virtue had its own rewards.
   b) Socrates says that virtue is its own rewards.
   c) Socrates said that virtue is its own reward.
   d) Socrates said that virtue was its own rewards.

   Answer: a

5193. MR. SAM ASKED THE BOY IF HE COULD TELL HIM WHERE THE NEAREST POST OFFICE IS. :
   a) Where is the nearest post office ? Mr. Sam asked the boy.
   b) Mr. Sam asked the boy "Could you tell me where the nearest post office is"?
   c) Mr. Sam asked the boy "where is the nearest post office" ?
   d) Mr. Sam said to the boy "where is the nearest post office"?

   Answer: a

5194. HE ASKED ME WHY I WAS LATE. :
   a) He asked me, "Why I was late ?"
   b) He asked me, "Why you are late ?"
   c) He asked me, "Why am I late?"
   d) He asked me, "Why are you late?"

   Answer: a

5195. "ALRIGHT, YES, I WAS WRONG AND YOU WERE RIGHT", HE SAID. :
   a) He admitted that I was wrong and you were right.
   b) He admitted that I was wrong and he was right.
   c) He admitted that he had been wrong and I had been right.
   d) He admitted that he has been wrong and I have been right.

   Answer: a

   b) I said to my brother, "Have you returned the money to your friend?"
   c) Do you return the money to his friend.
   d) Had you returned the money to my friend.

   Answer: a

   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

5333. (I) I OWN THAT BOOK. (II) THAT BOOK BELONGS TO ME. (III) THAT BOOK IS MINE. :
   a) (i) and (ii)
   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

5334. (I) EVERYONE IN THE HOUSE HEARD ME SINGING IN THE SHOWER. (II) EVERYONE IN THE HOUSE HEARD MINE SINGING IN THE SHOWER. (III) EVERYONE IN THE HOUSE HEARD MY SINGING IN THE SHOWER. :
   a) (i) and (ii)
   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

   a) (i) and (ii)

   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

5432. I. BIRD / II. I WAS / III. AS FREE / IV. AS A THE CORRECT SEQUENCE FORMS: **I WAS AS FREE AS A BIRD.** :
   a) I-II-III-IV
   b) IV-I-II-III
   c) II-III-IV-I
   d) III-I-II-IV

   Answer: a

5433. I. THE FIRST FILM / II. HE EVER / III. THAT IS / IV. SAW THE CORRECT SEQUENCE FORMS: **THAT IS THE FIRST FILM HE EVER SAW.** :
   a) I-III-II-IV
   b) III-I-II-IV
   c) II-I-III-IV
   d) IV-III-I-II

   Answer: a

5434. I. BY HER INDULGENT PARENTS / II. THE CHILD WAS SO SPOILED / III. WHEN SHE DID NOT RECEIVE ALL OF / IV. THAT SHE POUTED AND BECAME SULLEN / THEIR ATTENTION THE CORRECT SEQUENCE FORMS: **THE CHILD WAS SO SPOILED BY HER INDULGENT PARENTS THAT SHE POUTED AND BECAME SULLEN WHEN SHE DID NOT RECEIVE ALL OF THEIR ATTENTION.** (NOTE: THE OPTIONS PROVIDED SEEM TO FOLLOW THE STRUCTURE: [II]...[I]...[IV]...[III]. THE MOST LOGICAL ORDER IS II-I-IV-III.) :
   a) II-I-IV-III
   b) III-IV-II-I
   c) I-IV-III-II
   d) II-III-IV-I

   Answer: a

5435. I. THAT / II. RACIALISM / III. SHOULD BE WIPED OUT / IV. PEOPLE WANT THE CORRECT SEQUENCE FORMS: **PEOPLE WANT THAT RACIALISM SHOULD BE WIPED OUT.** :
   a) II-III-I-IV
   b) IV-II-III-I
   c) IV-I-II-III
   d) I-II-IV-III

   Answer: a

5436. I. CHECKED REGULARLY / II. YOU SHOULD HAVE / III. BLOOD PRESSURE / IV. YOUR THE CORRECT SEQUENCE FORMS: **YOU SHOULD HAVE YOUR BLOOD PRESSURE CHECKED REGULARLY.** :
   a) IV-III-I-II
   b) I-IV-III-II
   c) II-I-IV-III
   d) II-IV-III-I

   Answer: a

5442. WHY WAS S. NALINI SENTENCED TO LIFETIME IMPRISONMENT BY THE JUDICIARY OF THE COUNTRY? :
   a) She murdered a lot of people during her school days and that came out in the open later
   b) She murdered her family out of mercy though her husband had left her for another woman before that
   c) She did not do anything but the court was of the view that she could do something if left to fend for herself within the society
   d) She was involved in the assassination of the former Prime Minister of India

   Answer: a

5443. WHICH AMONG THE FOLLOWING IS CORRECT REGARDING THE ATTITUDE OF THE STATE GOVERNMENT TOWARDS THE SENTENCE OF LIFE IMPRISONMENT GIVEN TO S. NALINI? :
   a) The State Government has nothing to say in the whole issue since the case was dealt with by the Central Government.
   b) The State Government could not understand the fact that there was nothing wrong done by S. Nalini many years ago.
   c) The State Government is of the opinion that the sentence given to S. Nalini can be remitted at once.
   d) The State Government wants the convict to continue with the given sentence by the court for the crime committed by her.

   Answer: a

5444. WHICH AMONG THE FOLLOWING ARE NOT CORRECT AS PER THE GIVEN PASSAGE? I. THIS IS THE FIRST TIME THAT S. NALINI HAS BEEN GIVEN THE PERMISSION TO COME OUT ON PAROLE. II. S. NALINI HAS BEEN GRANTED THE RIGHT TO COME OUT ON PAROLE TO PERFORM THE LAST RITES OF HER HUSBAND. III. S. NALINI HAS NO CHILD AND THAT IS WHY SHE IS NOT AT ALL HAPPY WITH THE SENTENCE. :
   a) Both I and II
   b) Both II and III
   c) Both I and III
   d) All I, II and III

   Answer: a

5445. WHICH AMONG THE FOLLOWING IS/ARE CORRECT REGARDING THE OBSERVATIONS OF THE MADRAS HIGH COURT REGARDING S. NALINI? I. S. NALINI IS A VERY RICH WOMAN AND THAT IS WHY NO MONETARY SUPPORT IS REQUIRED TO BE GIVEN TO HER. II. S. NALINI IS A DREADED CRIMINAL AND THAT IS WHY SHE SHOULD BE PUT BEHIND THE BARS FOR LIFE WITH NO CHANCE AT ANY KIND OF REFORMATION. III. S. NALINI HAS INTENTIONALLY JEOPARDIZED HER RELATIONSHIP WITH HER HUSBAND AND THAT IS WHY SHE SHOULD BE PUNISHED FOR THAT. :
   a) None of I, II and III
   b) Both I and II
   c) Both II and III
   d) Both I and III

   Answer: a

5452. FOOD WHICH AGREES WITH ONE'S TASTE :

   c) are
   d) No errors

   Answer: d

5876. WHICH AMONG THE FOLLOWING IS CORRECT REGARDING THE ATTITUDE OF THE STATE GOVERNMENT TOWARDS THE SENTENCE OF LIFE IMPRISONMENT GIVEN TO S. NALINI? :
   a) The State Government has nothing to say in the whole issue since the case was dealt with by the Central Government.
   b) The State Government could not understand the fact that there was nothing wrong done by S. Nalini many years ago.
   c) The State Government is of the opinion that the sentence given to S. Nalini can be remitted at once.
   d) The State Government wants the convict to continue with the given sentence by the court for the crime committed by her.

   Answer: a

5877. WHICH AMONG THE FOLLOWING ARE NOT CORRECT AS PER THE GIVEN PASSAGE? I. THIS IS THE FIRST TIME THAT S. NALINI HAS BEEN GIVEN THE PERMISSION TO COME OUT ON PAROLE. II. S. NALINI HAS BEEN GRANTED THE RIGHT TO COME OUT ON PAROLE TO PERFORM THE LAST RITES OF HER HUSBAND. III. S. NALINI HAS NO CHILD AND THAT IS WHY SHE IS NOT AT ALL HAPPY WITH THE SENTENCE. :
   a) Both I and II
   b) Both II and III
   c) Both I and III
   d) All I, II and III

   Answer: a

5878. WHICH AMONG THE FOLLOWING IS/ARE CORRECT REGARDING THE OBSERVATIONS OF THE MADRAS HIGH COURT REGARDING S. NALINI? I. S. NALINI IS A VERY RICH WOMAN AND THAT IS WHY NO MONETARY SUPPORT IS REQUIRED TO BE GIVEN TO HER. II. S. NALINI IS A DREADED CRIMINAL AND THAT IS WHY SHE SHOULD BE PUT BEHIND THE BARS FOR LIFE WITH NO CHANCE AT ANY KIND OF REFORMATION. III. S. NALINI HAS INTENTIONALLY JEOPARDIZED HER RELATIONSHIP WITH HER HUSBAND AND THAT IS WHY SHE SHOULD BE PUNISHED FOR THAT. :
   a) Both I and II
   b) Both II and III
   c) Both I and III
   d) None of I, II and III

   Answer: a

   b) Vehement
   c) Feeling

   b) I-III-IV-II
   c) IV-III-II-I
   d) III-IV-II-I

   Answer: a

5881. I. ANDHRA PRADESH ON MONDAY MORNING II. EMISAT, FROM SRIHARIKOTA IN COASTAL III. THE INDIAN SPACE RESEARCH ORGANISATION (ISRO) LAUNCHED IV. THE COUNTRY'S FIRST ELECTRONIC SURVEILLANCE SATELLITE :

   b) I-III-IV-II
   c) I-IV-III-II
   d) IV-III-II-I

   Answer: a

   b) I-II-III-IV
   c) II-III-IV-I
   d) III-I-II-IV

   Answer: a

   b) I-II-III-IV
   c) I-IV-III-II
   d) III-I-II-IV

   Answer: a

   b) II-I-IV-III

   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii) - CORRECT ANSWER
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

6146. (I) HAD I KNOWN, I WOULD HAVE CALLED YOU. (II) IF I KNEW, I WOULD HAVE CALLED YOU. (III) IF I WOULD HAVE KNOWN, I WOULD HAVE CALLED YOU. :
   a) (i) only - CORRECT ANSWER (Assuming the options are (i) only, (ii) only, etc., or based on the logic that only (i) is perfectly correct, though options are given as pairs.)
   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

6147. (I) CHARLES HAS BEEN WORKING FOR FIVE HOURS. (II) CHARLES HAS WORKED FOR FIVE HOURS. (III) CHARLES IS WORKING FOR FIVE HOURS. :
   a) (i) and (ii) - CORRECT ANSWER
   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

6148. (I) TRAVELLING AROUND THE WORLD IS HIS DREAM. (II) HE WANT TO TRAVEL AROUND THE WORLD. (III) TRAVELING AROUND THE WORLD IS HIS DREAM. :
   a) (i) and (ii)
   b) (i) and (iii) - CORRECT ANSWER
   c) (ii) and (iii)
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

6149. (I) I WILL FINISHED MY PROJECT TOMORROW. (II) I WILL HAVE FINISHED MY PROJECT BY TOMORROW. (III) I'LL BE DONE WITH MY PROJECT BY TOMORROW. :
   a) (i) and (ii)
   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii) - CORRECT ANSWER
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

   b) (i) and (iii)
   c) (ii) and (iii) - CORRECT ANSWER
   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

6242. WHEN ALBERT STAYED AT THE AFRICAN JUNGLE / HE CHOSE TO PUT UP WITH MANY INCONVENIENCES SUCH AS / WILD ANIMALS AND POISONOUS INSECTS. / NO ERROR :
   a) When Albert stayed at the African jungle - CORRECT ANSWER (Should be 'in the African jungle' or 'in the African jungles')
   b) he chose to put up with many inconveniences such as
   c) wild animals and poisonous insects.
   d) No error

   Answer: a

6243. EACH ONE OF HIS SISTERS / WERE / HARDWORKING. / NO ERROR :

   c) causes cancer cells to grow. - CORRECT ANSWER (Should be 'cause' as the subject 'doses' is plural)
   d) No error

   Answer: a

   b) distinct
   c) varied
   d) simple - CORRECT ANSWER

   Answer: a

6270. (A) GRATIFICATION - CORRECT ANSWER (SATISFACTION) :
   b) simplification
   c) purification
   d) identification

   Answer: a

6271. JUHI SAID TO HER FRIEND, "I CAN CHOOSE TO LIVE THE WAY I WANT TO." :
   a) Juhi told her friend that she can choose to live the way she want to.
   b) Juhi told her friend that she could be choosing to live the way she wants to.
   c) Juhi told her friend that she chooses to live the way she wanted to.
   d) Juhi told her friend that she could choose to live the way she wanted to. - CORRECT ANSWER

   Answer: a

6272. THE BOSS SAID TO THE SECRETARY, "BRING THE FILE THAT I HAD GIVEN TO YOU YESTERDAY." :
   a) The boss told the Secretary to bring the file that I had given to her the day before.
   b) The boss told his Secretary to bring the file that he gave her yesterday.
   c) The boss told the Secretary to bring the file that he had given to her the day before. - CORRECT ANSWER
   d) The boss had told the Secretary to bring the file that he had given to her yesterday.

   Answer: a

6273. "WHERE ARE YOU GOING?" FATHER ASKED ME. :
   a) Father asked me where I am going.
   b) Father asked me that where you are going.
   c) Father asked me where I would be going.
   d) Father asked me where I was going. - CORRECT ANSWER

   Answer: a

6274. MY FRIEND SAID TO ME, "I AM NOT GOING TO TALK TO YOU." :
   a) The friend told me that he would not be talking to me.
   b) The friend has told me that he is not going to talk to me.
   c) My friend told me that he was not going to talk to me. - CORRECT ANSWER
   d) The friend has told me that he is never going to talk with me.

   Answer: a

6275. THE CARPENTERS WILL TAKE A MONTH'S TIME TO MAKE THE FURNITURE. :
   a) A month's time is took by the carpenter to make the furniture.
   b) The carpenters to make the furniture will take a month's time.
   c) A month's time will be taken by the carpenter to make the furniture. - CORRECT ANSWER
   d) Making of the furniture by the carpenters will take a month's time.

   Answer: a

6276. THE CITY WILL BUILD A NEW BRIDGE ACROSS THE RIVER. :
   a) A new bridge across the river will be built by the city. - CORRECT ANSWER
   b) A bridge which is new will be built by the city.
   c) Building of a new bridge will be done by the city.
   d) The city will be building a new bridge across the river.

   Answer: a

6277. GRANDMOTHER IS KNITTING A SWEATER FOR YOU. :
   a) A sweater is being knit by grandmother for you. - CORRECT ANSWER
   b) A sweater will be knit by grandmother for you.
   c) Grandmother is knitting for you a sweater.
   d) Knitting of a sweater has been done by grandmother for you.

   Answer: a

6278. TWO ENGINES ARE PULLING THE TRAIN UP THE HILL. :
   a) The train will be pulled up the hill by two engines.
   b) Up the hill pulling of the train is being done by the two engines.
   c) The train is being pulled up the hill by two engines. - CORRECT ANSWER
   d) Two engines are needed for pulling the train up the hill.

   Answer: a

6279. (A) ORTHOPEADIC :
   b) Orthopadic
   c) Orthopaedic - CORRECT ANSWER
   d) Orthopedic

   Answer: a

6280. (A) MISCELLANEOUS - CORRECT ANSWER :
   b) Micellaneous
   c) Misellaneous
   d) Miscelaneous

   Answer: a

6281. (A) DIARRHOEA - CORRECT ANSWER :
   b) Diarrehia
   c) Diariheoa
   d) Diarihoea

   Answer: a

6282. 1. THE MASTER RETURNED HOME AFTER SOMETIME. / 6. HE REALIZED THAT HIS DOG HAD SAVED HIS BABY. P. THE SNAKE WAS LYING DEAD UNDER THE CRADLE. Q. HE WENT INTO THE ROOM WHERE THE BABY WAS SLEEPING. R. IT HAD BEEN KILLED BY HIS DOG. S. HE NOTICED A SNAKE. :
   a) SRPQ
   b) QRPS
   c) QSPR - CORRECT ANSWER (1 -> Q -> S -> P -> R -> 6)
   d) PQRS

   Answer: a

6283. 1. ADVERSITY IS A CURSE. / 6. THIS DEVELOPS OUR LATENT POWERS, ENABLING US TO PROSPER IN LIFE. P. WHEN EVERYTHING GOES ON WELL, WE ARE TEMPTED TO TAKE MATTERS EASY. Q. BUT, IT HAS ITS USES ALSO. R. BUT ADVERSITY PROMPTS US TO EXERT OURSELVES. S. WE FALL INTO A LIFE OF COMFORT AND IDLENESS. :
   a) SPQR - CORRECT ANSWER (1 -> S -> P -> Q -> R -> 6 is the most logical flow if P and S are reversed, but SPQR is an option; 1 -> S: fall into comfort/idleness -> P: When everything goes well (cause of S) -> Q: uses also (contrast) -> R: prompts us to exert (key use) -> 6: develops powers.)
   b) PRQS
   c) QRSP
   d) QSRP

   Answer: a

6284. 1. A TRAVELLER HAD SPENT MANY A YEAR IN AFRICA. / 6. "I RAN, AND THEY RAN AFTER ME!" P. "HOW DID YOU MANAGE IT?" ASKED ONE OF HIS FRIENDS, GREATLY IMPRESSED. Q. ON HIS RETURN HOME, HE NARRATED HIS ADVENTURES TO HIS FRIENDS. R. "OH, IT WAS NOTHING", REPLIED THE TRAVELLER. S. "WHEN I WAS IN EL DOAB", HE SAID, "I MADE FIFTY ARABS RUN!" :
   a) RPQS
   b) QRSP
   c) QSPR - CORRECT ANSWER (1 -> Q: narrated -> S: told the story -> P: friend asked -> R: traveller replied -> 6: punchline)
   d) PQSR

   Answer: a

6285. 1. WE WANTED TO RELAX AND HAVE FUN. / 6. WE ENJOYED OURSELVES A LOT AND FELT A WELCOME CHANGE IN OUR MONOTONOUS LIFE. P. ALL OF US AGREED TO SHARE RESPONSIBILITIES. Q. TWO OF US TOOK OUR CARS. R. WE DECIDED TO GO FOR A PICNIC TO GOLF LINKS. S. EACH ONE OF US BROUGHT ONE DISH, SOME FRUITS AND SWEETS. :
   a) QSPR
   b) PRQS
   c) RPQS - CORRECT ANSWER (1 -> R: decided -> P: agreed to share -> Q: took cars -> S: brought food -> 6: enjoyed)
   d) SRPQ

   Answer: a

6286. A STATE OF DECADENCE HAS COME ABOUT BECAUSE OF :
   a) indiscriminate utilization of resources
   b) half-hearted attempts
   c) natural disasters
   d) None of the above - CORRECT ANSWER (The text specifies "indiscriminate industrialization")

   Answer: a

   b) i and iii

   c) embarrassment

   d) to indulge

   Answer: a

   b) frustrate
   c) impede
   d) assure

   b) **fertile**

   d) pure

6376. (I) SHE IS TOO PROUD TO ASK ANYONE TO HELP HER. (II) SHE IS SO PROUD THAT SHE WILL NOT ASK ANYONE TO HELP HER. (III) SHE IS TOO PROUD TO ASK. :

   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

6380. (I) SHE COULD NOT ATTEND THE WEDDING AS SHE WAS ILL. (II) SHE COULD NOT ATTEND THE WEDDING ON ACCOUNT OF HER ILLNESS. (III) SHE COULD NOT BE ILL TO ATTEND THE WEDDING. :

   d) (i), (ii) and (iii)

   Answer: a

6530. AWNING :
   a) Cover usually of canvas
   b) A log cabin
   c) Uncovered area
   d) Open space

   Answer: a

6531. WHEN ARJUN SAW IT, HIS FACE WENT **AS WHITE AS A SHEET**. :
   a) very bad temper
   b) clean as snow
   c) pale with fear
   d) become very angry

   Answer: c

6532. KELLY HAS A **HEART OF GOLD**. :

   b) hard hearted
   c) distant and unfriendly
   d) well-behaved

   Answer: a

   b) very gradually
   c) almost instantaneously
   d) to write very well

   d) No error

6611. WHAT IS ONE OF THE PRIMARY ECOLOGICAL ROLES OF THE AMAZON RAINFOREST? :
   a) Providing freshwater to South America
   b) Regulating the Earth's climate by absorbing carbon dioxide
   c) Producing oil and natural gas
   d) Acting as a barrier against natural disasters

   Answer: b

   a) Fishing and tourism
   b) Cattle ranching and soybean farming
   c) Urban development and water pollution
   d) Hunting and road construction

   Answer: b

6613. WHAT HAPPENS WHEN TREES IN THE AMAZON ARE CUT DOWN? :
   a) The oxygen levels in the atmosphere increase
   b) Carbon stored in the trees is released into the atmosphere
   c) The soil becomes more fertile for agriculture
   d) Wildlife population increases due to habitat expansion

   Answer: b

6614. WHAT ARE SOME EFFORTS BEING MADE TO PROTECT THE AMAZON RAINFOREST? :

   b) Encouraging deforestation for economic growth
   c) Reforestation projects and stricter land use regulations
   d) Relocating indigenous communities

   Answer: c

6615. WHAT IS THE MAIN CONCERN REGARDING THE FUTURE OF THE AMAZON RAINFOREST? :
   a) Economic pressures may continue to drive deforestation.
   b) Tourism will damage the rainforest.
   c) The Amazon will stop producing oxygen altogether.
   d) The Amazon will be turned into a national park.

   Answer: a

   b) I and III
   c) II and III

   b) I and III
   c) II and III
   d) I, II and III

   Answer: a

   d) by
